title: 103_s634
content: The "A Better Chance to Learn Act of 1993" aims to support innovative home-based parent and early childhood education programs to empower parents, enhance school-readiness skills, promote positive attitudes towards education, and involve parents in the transition to kindergarten. The Act defines key terms such as community-based organizations, developmentally appropriate, home-based, and limited or unsuccessful formal schooling. The term "limited or unsuccessful formal schooling" refers to low achievement in high school or lack of a general education degree. "Local educational agencies" are defined as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. "Near poor families" are those with an income around 130 percent of the poverty line. Parent education includes support activities, resource materials on child development, educational guidance, and learning experiences for parents and children to improve learning at home. Working poor families are defined as those with family members who are working or actively seeking employment. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education. SEC. 4. PROGRAM AUTHORIZED. The Secretary can award grants to local agencies and organizations for home-based parent and early childhood education programs. Grants are divided equally between new programs and existing ones. Priority is given to programs targeting working poor or near poor families. The Secretary can award grants to local agencies and organizations for home-based parent and early childhood education programs. Grants are divided equally between new programs and existing ones, with priority given to working poor or near poor families, families not served by existing programs, and parents with limited formal schooling. Authorized activities under this Act include establishing, operating, or expanding home-based parent and early childhood education programs. Eligibility for grants requires entities to submit an application with necessary information to the Secretary. Program requirements are outlined in section 7. The Act requires grantees to conduct a home-based parent and early childhood education program that enhances parents' awareness of their role as primary educators, provides necessary support and materials for a school-readiness program, conducts group meetings for parenting skills, and offers field trip opportunities. Eligible participants are outlined in section 8. SEC. 8 outlines eligibility for parent and early childhood service programs under the Act, requiring participants to be parents of children aged 3, 4, or 5. Special rules include voluntary participation and no infringement on parents' education rights. SEC. 9 outlines the Federal and Non-Federal share of contributions for programs established under the Act. The Federal share is set at 80 percent, while the grantee must provide a non-Federal contribution of at least 20 percent, which can be in cash or in kind. SEC. 10 states that funds from the Act should supplement, not replace, local public funds for services for eligible individuals. Authorization of appropriations for this Act includes $20,000,000 for fiscal year 1994 and necessary sums for fiscal years 1995 through 1998.
